review_title: This is the reason I bought VR
one_reviews_text:
Had no idea this would end up being the reason I have VR.  I originally bought my Rift for iRacing, and it works really well for that.  But I took a break from sim racing and my Rift started collecting dust.  I happened to see Bigscreen recently, read some of the reviews, and gave it a try.  Now it's my favorite VR app by a huge margin.  

Bigscreen is the closest thing to playing any game in VR.  The main thing I wanted from VR was the ability to play existing games in a more immersive perspective with a normal gamepad.  Playing in Bigscreen isn’t technically "VR," but it might as well be when you have a huge screen wrapped in front of you, encompassing your entire vision.  When I was doing some dogfighting in BF:V, my stomach was turning just like it would in VR.  Luckily I’m not very susceptible to motion sickness.  

On the complete opposite end of the comfort spectrum, you can finally put a huge screen on the ceiling and watch movies laying down.  Once I started using Bigscreen, I bought HDMI/USB 3.0 extensions so my headset can reach anywhere in the room.  Now I can control my computer, play games, and watch movies while sitting, standing, laying, or doing frickin power lunges and jumping jacks if I wanted.  

It's also easy to use, and works flawlessly for the most part.  Occasionally, I'll have issues trying to control the mouse on the desktop with the touch controllers, but that could just as easily be the fault of the touch controllers or Windows.  Once you launch into a fullscreen game and start using a gamepad, everything works great.  Battlefield V ran twice as smooth when I switched from a 120hz screen to a 60hz one and used Vsync.  So if things don't look smooth in Bigscreen for you, try lowering your monitor's refresh rate to something equal to or less than your headset (90hz).

This is a fun little app and just what I was looking for and it's free! There are plenty of ways to view video and windows in VR. But I was looking for a proper theater experience with a proper size screen at the proper distance. This app does that nicely. The ‘big cinema’ environment feels just like you are there. The only thing missing is the popcorn smell and that’s easy enough to add and I did.
It needs more ‘big cinema’ type environments as the small screen environments just don’t have the same impact for watching movies. The home theater environment makes it feel like you’re watching in a home theater but to me that doesn’t have the same impact as a big screen. A 10’ screen viewed at 10’ may fill the same field of view in your vision as a 50’ screen at 50’ but for some reason it just doesn’t have the same psychological impact. Plus focusing at infinity is easier on the eyes (for most people) so a screen that is far away is less eye straining. Point being that more big screen environments would be great for watching movies. I’m old enough to remember drive-ins and that would be a great environment for movies. With in-car seating option complete with interiors and the option for tinny sound from a speaker hanging from your window. Then of course you can have the outside lawn chair, car hood and snack bar table seating options. That would be a fun environment for getting together in.
Another would be ‘movies in the pool’. I’ve always enjoyed this in real life and I’d probably be fun in VR too. Do forget the poolside bar. Which reminds me. Stock up on straws because pretty much anything but a bottle is a pain to drink from while wearing a VR headset and I don’t know about you but I snack when I watch movies.
Of course the other cool feature is that you can host a public or private room for whatever activity you want. But that also makes me wonder about copyright law and how long these types of apps will be around once VR is mainstream. There is nothing to stop me

review_feedback: This is 100% FALSE. We do not record and we do not broadcast anything when you download the app. You have to OPT IN to join a multiplayer room if you WANT to share your desktop screen. That is the purpose of Bigscreen's multiplayer features, as described in Oculus Home. It lets you do screensharing with social VR features. This lets you watch a movie with your friends, or play games together, or just hangout. In fact, our streaming is entirely Peer-to-Peer encrypted, meaning there isn't even a server. Bigscreen can never "see" your data or your desktop. Only the people in your multiplayer room. If you have any privacy concerns, you can email me directly and I'm happy to explain to you how this works. darshan@bigscreenvr.com

review_title: Agreed that it's the best social VR
one_reviews_text: I spent about 50 hours so far just playing Zelda on Dolphin while people came in and hung out. Best VR experience so far. Extremely active devs. The only downside is the Oculus resolution limitations.
This is truly a groundbreaking application. The fact that I can stream a movie and watch it with people from far away in VR is fantastic.
Very nice app, compared to something like Steam desktop it's out of it's league! The graphics are how they are supposed to be, you can actually watch movies, do stuff on desktop. Really nice!
Great active development team, packed full of features and executed perfectly. Use your desktop pc in VR and share with friends old and new.
Love this already. Very well thought through, creates a great space. I think this app could own the social platform for all VR.
